articles.headline: Car Sales Jumped in February, but Here Come Gas Prices Again
articles.snippet: While consumers mostly avoided S.U.V.’s and trucks a few years ago, their sales jumped more than cars in February.
articles.abstract: While consumers mostly avoided S.U.V.’s and trucks a few years ago, their sales jumped more than cars in February.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Sales of new vehicles in the United States increased 27 percent in February, automakers said Tuesday, even as violence in the Middle East and a surge in gasoline prices threatened to slow the industry’s postrecession recovery.

articles.headline: More College Graduates Take Public Service Jobs
articles.snippet: A cohort of young graduates has done good because the economy did them wrong, data show.
articles.abstract: A cohort of young graduates has done good because the economy did them wrong, data show.
articles.lead_paragraph: If Alison Sadock had finished college before the financial crisis, she probably would have done something corporate. Maybe a job in retail, or finance, or brand management at a big company  the kind of work her oldest sister, who graduated in the economically effervescent year of 2005, does at PepsiCo.

articles.headline: Wastewater Recycling No Cure-All in Gas Process
articles.snippet: Though it has helped the natural gas industry reduce its wastewater, recycling has not eliminated all the hazards.
articles.abstract: Though it has helped the natural gas industry reduce its wastewater, recycling has not eliminated all the hazards.
articles.lead_paragraph: As drilling for natural gas started to climb sharply about 10 years ago, energy companies faced mounting criticism over an extraction process that involves pumping millions of gallons of water into the ground for each well and can leave significant amounts of hazardous contaminants in the water that comes back to the surface.

articles.headline: Uncertainty Drives Up Oil Prices
articles.snippet: Any interruptions from countries like Iran, Oman and Iraq would further tighten oil supplies.
articles.abstract: Any interruptions from countries like Iran, Oman and Iraq would further tighten oil supplies.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  Just when oil markets appeared to be calming, crude oil prices surged again on Tuesday as the potential for more oil shipment disruptions spread across the Middle East and North Africa.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Japan Phone Makers See Opportunity in Android
articles.snippet: Sharp, Sony Ericsson and others are hoping that Google’s system will finally help Japan’s cellphones catch fire abroad.
articles.abstract: Sharp, Sony Ericsson and others are hoping that Google’s system will finally help Japan’s cellphones catch fire abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Japanese mobile phones are a gadget lover’s dream. They double as credit cards. They can display digital TV broadcasts. Some are even fitted with solar cells.

articles.headline: Union Contracts, Not Pay, Are States’ Problem
articles.snippet: The real labor issue involving public workers is not the money — it’s almost everything else.
articles.abstract: The real labor issue involving public workers is not the money — it’s almost everything else.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Ed Rendell became the mayor of Philadelphia in 1992, he started a fight with the city’s labor unions that will sound familiar to anyone who has been following the recent news from Wisconsin. In his inaugural address, Mr. Rendell, a Democrat, announced, “Philadelphia stands on the brink of total disaster.”

articles.headline: Galliano Case Tests Dior Brand’s Future
articles.snippet: Troubled by the actions of its star designer, John Galliano, Christian Dior acted quickly and decisively in an effort to limit any long-term damage to the brand.
articles.abstract: Troubled by the actions of its star designer, John Galliano, Christian Dior acted quickly and decisively in an effort to limit any long-term damage to the brand.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The career of Christian Dior’s star designer, John Galliano, may well be over after he was dismissed Tuesday for a video that surfaced of him making anti-Semitic remarks. But Dior — and its parent company, LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton — acted quickly and decisively in an attempt to limit any long-term damage to the Dior name.

articles.headline: Arab Unrest Puts Their Lobbyists in Uneasy Spot
articles.snippet: Washington lobbyists for Arab nations are trying to stay ahead of events without being seen as aiding despots.
articles.abstract: Washington lobbyists for Arab nations are trying to stay ahead of events without being seen as aiding despots.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  For years, they have been one of the most formidable lobbying forces in town: the elite band of former members of Congress, former diplomats and power brokers who have helped Middle Eastern nations navigate diplomatic waters here on delicate issues like arms deals, terrorism, oil and trade restrictions.

articles.headline: Credit Card Data Tells Mixed Story
articles.snippet: While some consumers spent more during the holidays because the economy was rebounding, others leaned on their credit cards to cover expenses.
articles.abstract: While some consumers spent more during the holidays because the economy was rebounding, others leaned on their credit cards to cover expenses.
articles.lead_paragraph: American shoppers did not shed their reliance on credit cards over the year-end holidays.

articles.headline: Extremists Are Suspected in Killing of Pakistani Minister
articles.snippet: The minister of minorities, Shahbaz Bhatti, a Christian, was ambushed in an attack similar to the recent killing of another liberal politician.
articles.abstract: The minister of minorities, Shahbaz Bhatti, a Christian, was ambushed in an attack similar to the recent killing of another liberal politician.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan  The only Christian cabinet minister in the Pakistani government was shot dead Wednesday two months after the assassination of another liberal politician, raising questions about how firmly Pakistan’s government is tackling Islamist extremism.

articles.headline: Rebels in Libya Win Battle but Fail to Loosen Qaddafi’s Grip
articles.snippet: From the feeble cover of sand dunes, assaulted by a warplane and artillery from a hill, rebels repelled an attack by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s fighters.
articles.abstract: From the feeble cover of sand dunes, assaulted by a warplane and artillery from a hill, rebels repelled an attack by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s fighters.
articles.lead_paragraph: BREGA, Libya  From the feeble cover of sand dunes, under assault from a warplane overhead and heavy artillery from a hill, rebels in this strategic oil city repelled an attack by hundreds of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s fighters on Wednesday. The daylong battle was the first major incursion by the colonel’s forces in the rebel-held east of the country since the Libyan uprising began.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and Robert F. Worth
